diagnosis.pearl: AF begets AF - Electrical and structural remodeling makes AF self-perpetuating
diagnosis.clinical_significance: Early rhythm control may prevent progression from paroxysmal to persistent AF
diagnosis.evidence: EARLY-AF trial showed benefit of early ablation

diagnosis.pearl: Holiday Heart Syndrome - AF triggered by acute alcohol ingestion
diagnosis.clinical_significance: Even moderate drinking (>1 drink/day) increases AF risk
diagnosis.management: Alcohol cessation can reduce AF recurrence by 50%

diagnosis.pearl: Lone AF - AF without structural heart disease in patients <60 years
diagnosis.clinical_significance: Lower stroke risk but still follow CHADSVASC guidelines
diagnosis.prognosis: Generally good but may progress with age

diagnosis.pearl: PAC burden >100/hour predicts development of AF
diagnosis.clinical_significance: Monitor patients with frequent PACs on Holter
diagnosis.intervention: Consider lifestyle modifications, treat sleep apnea

anticoagulation.pearl: DOACs have 50% lower ICH risk than warfarin (0.3% vs 0.8% annually)
anticoagulation.cost_consideration: Cost-effective due to reduced monitoring and complications

anticoagulation.pearl: Fall risk should NOT prevent anticoagulation in appropriate patients
anticoagulation.evidence: Need 295 falls/year to offset stroke prevention benefit
anticoagulation.approach: Address fall risk factors, consider gait training

anticoagulation.pearl: Time in therapeutic range (TTR) <70% warfarin patients should switch to DOAC
anticoagulation.rationale: Poor INR control negates warfarin benefits
anticoagulation.implementation: Use anticoagulation clinics to optimize TTR first

anticoagulation.pearl: CHADSVASC score more predictive than CHADS2 in low-risk patients
anticoagulation.difference: CHADSVASC better identifies truly low-risk patients (score 0-1)
anticoagulation.clinical_impact: Reduces unnecessary anticoagulation in young women

rate_vs_rhythm_control.pearl: Rate control non-inferior to rhythm control for most patients
rate_vs_rhythm_control.evidence: AFFIRM, RACE trials showed no mortality difference
rate_vs_rhythm_control.implications: Focus on symptom improvement rather than rhythm

rate_vs_rhythm_control.pearl: Rhythm control beneficial in young, symptomatic patients
rate_vs_rhythm_control.evidence: CABANA, EAST-AFNET 4 suggest early rhythm control beneficial

rate_vs_rhythm_control.pearl: Lenient rate control (<110 bpm) adequate for most patients
rate_vs_rhythm_control.evidence: RACE II trial showed non-inferiority to strict control
rate_vs_rhythm_control.exception: Use strict control (<80 bpm) if symptomatic

cardioversion.pearl: AF <48h duration can be cardioverted without anticoagulation if low stroke risk
cardioversion.caveat: Consider TEE if clinical uncertainty about duration
cardioversion.post_cardioversion: Still need 4 weeks anticoagulation due to atrial stunning

cardioversion.indications: Patient preference, urgent need for rhythm control

cardioversion.pearl: Atrial stunning occurs after cardioversion regardless of method
cardioversion.duration: Up to 4 weeks, requires continued anticoagulation

common_pitfalls.pitfall: Using AV nodal blockers (CCB, digoxin) in WPW with AF
common_pitfalls.consequence: Can accelerate ventricular rate via accessory pathway
common_pitfalls.recognition: Delta waves on ECG, very rapid irregular rhythm
common_pitfalls.management: IV procainamide or ibutilide, avoid adenosine/verapamil

common_pitfalls.problem: Atrial stunning persists 4 weeks, high recurrence rate
common_pitfalls.correct_approach: Continue anticoagulation ≥4 weeks, then reassess CHADSVASC

common_pitfalls.pitfall: Using Class IC antiarrhythmics in CAD/structural heart disease
common_pitfalls.screening: Always obtain echo and stress test before Class IC
common_pitfalls.alternative: Amiodarone or dofetilide in structural disease

common_pitfalls.pitfall: Not adjusting DOAC doses for renal function
common_pitfalls.problem: Accumulation and bleeding risk with renal impairment
common_pitfalls.monitoring: Check CrCl every 6-12 months, adjust accordingly

common_pitfalls.pitfall: Withholding anticoagulation solely based on HAS-BLED score
common_pitfalls.misunderstanding: HAS-BLED predicts bleeding risk but shouldn't prevent anticoagulation
common_pitfalls.correct_use: Identify modifiable bleeding risks, inform shared decision-making

common_pitfalls.pitfall: Using immediate-release metoprolol for rate control
common_pitfalls.problem: BID dosing reduces compliance, less cardioprotective

common_pitfalls.pitfall: Not checking thyroid function in new-onset AF
common_pitfalls.prevalence: Hyperthyroidism found in 13% of new AF diagnoses
common_pitfalls.management: TSH should be checked in all patients with new AF

safety_alerts.alert: DOAC + Dual antiplatelet therapy = High bleeding risk
safety_alerts.management: Limit triple therapy duration, prefer P2Y12 inhibitor + DOAC

safety_alerts.alert: Amiodarone pulmonary toxicity can be fatal
safety_alerts.recognition: New cough, dyspnea, fever, bilateral infiltrates

safety_alerts.symptoms: N/V, visual changes, arrhythmias, altered mental status
safety_alerts.prevention: Dose based on age/CrCl, check levels, monitor K+/Mg2+
safety_alerts.management: Hold digoxin, correct electrolytes, consider Fab fragments

safety_alerts.presentation: Fever, sepsis, neurologic symptoms 1-4 weeks post-ablation
safety_alerts.prevention: Esophageal temperature monitoring, reduced posterior wall power

safety_alerts.alert: Dofetilide requires inpatient initiation with telemetry
safety_alerts.rationale: QT prolongation and torsades risk highest in first 3 days
safety_alerts.protocol: 3-day admission, QTc monitoring after each dose

case_based_learning.presentation: 25-year-old marathon runner with palpitations during training
key_points: Consider lone AF vs secondary causes
Exercise-induced AF may be vagally mediated
Class IC drugs effective if structurally normal heart
Ablation often first-line in young athletes
management_pearls: Obtain exercise stress test and echo
Consider EP study if WPW suspected

case_based_learning.presentation: 68-year-old man develops AF on POD#2 after CABG
key_points: Usually self-limited but increases length of stay
management_approach: Amiodarone 400mg BID x 1 week, then 200mg daily
Usually resolves within days to weeks

case_based_learning.case_title: AF with RVR in Heart Failure
case_based_learning.presentation: 75-year-old woman with HFrEF presents with AF RVR and decompensation
key_points: AF and HF have bidirectional relationship
Rate control crucial but limited by hypotension
management_strategy: Careful IV metoprolol with BP monitoring
Add digoxin for additional rate control

case_based_learning.presentation: 82-year-old with AF, CHADSVASC 4, history of falls
teaching_points: Fall risk should not prevent appropriate anticoagulation
DOACs preferred over warfarin in elderly
Consider reduced doses based on age/weight/renal function
decision_making: Stroke risk (8.5%/year) >> bleeding risk from falls

high_yield_facts: Female sex only counts if other risk factors present
common_mistakes: Forgetting that female sex requires other risk factors to count
Not doubling points for age ≥75 and stroke/TIA history

key_associations: Amiodarone: Safe in structural disease but multiple toxicities
Dofetilide: Requires inpatient initiation, good for HF/post-MI
Sotalol: Beta-blocker + Class III, QT prolongation risk

algorithm: <48h + low stroke risk: Can cardiovert without anticoagulation
>48h or unknown: 3 weeks pre + 4 weeks post anticoagulation
TEE-guided: Exclude thrombus → immediate cardioversion → 4 weeks anticoagulation
Emergency cardioversion: Proceed immediately, start anticoagulation ASAP

common_gaps: Patient refusal not addressed with education

emerging_concepts.evidence: EAST-AFNET 4 trial showed benefit of early rhythm control
emerging_concepts.definition: Rhythm control within 1 year of AF diagnosis
emerging_concepts.implications: May change paradigm from rate-first to early rhythm control

emerging_concepts.concept: Amount of AF (burden) may be more important than presence/absence

emerging_concepts.evidence: LEGACY trial showed 10% weight loss reduces AF
emerging_concepts.components: Weight loss, exercise, sleep apnea treatment, alcohol reduction
emerging_concepts.effectiveness: Can be as effective as antiarrhythmic drugs

emerging_concepts.potential: May improve safety profile of AF ablation

key_messages: Blood thinners work even if AF comes and goes
addressing_concerns: Bleeding fear: Explain low ICH risk with DOACs
Lifestyle impact: Emphasize freedom from monitoring

evidence_based: 10% weight loss can reduce AF episodes by 50%
Sleep apnea treatment reduces AF burden
Regular exercise beneficial but avoid extreme endurance
